title: Self-Portrait in a Flat Cap (Winter), first state
transcript:
NARRATOR: With an economic downturn at home and the rising threat of fascism abroad, artists of the 1930s confronted hard truths and real fears, seeking a new vision of America.

Looking to dusty landscapes and gritty city scenes, artists including Edward Hopper, Georgia O’Keeffe, and Grant Wood forged a vibrant American modernism. Featuring music and media of the time, with insightful commentary from Art Institute curators, this tour takes on an often overlooked and surprisingly influential period.
